description:
"ç‡ƒãˆã‚ˆï¼å§‰å·ã®æˆ¦ã„ (Burn! Battle of Anegawa)"

The issue game covers the early important battle of Oda Nobunaga, with his ally Tokugawa, against the Azai-Asakura alliance.

The game is a grand tactical combat game.  It emphasizes on initiative and army morale. The mechanics accelerates the collapse of losing army dramatically.

Game components:

    8 page rulebook
    150 counters
    1 map

This game covers the last battle around Meiji-Ishin.
One of the important Bakumatsu people, Takamori Saigoh decided to make a revolt in his home area, Satsuma (Kagoshima) in 1877 against his old friends and partners inside Meiji government.
The map covers the whole Kyushu island and uses point to point system.
The game has only 48 counters.  This is a small second game, but players can focus the important strategic decisions.
The victory is basically determined by Saigoh's end.
Historically he killed himself in the middle of his losing battle.
But, in this game, if Saigoh player cleverly play the game, there's a chance of bloody stalemate which means that he can propose some of his desire to the government for this revolt.

("I love you, Poland!) a trivia game with questions about Polish history, culture, sport and movie celebrities, and songs. uses talisman-style roll-and-move mechanic. players need to answer correctly questions in each of 6 different categories on the way to the finish space in the center.

Armored Trooper Votoms: The Battling Card Game (
è£…ç”²é¨Žå…µãƒœãƒˆãƒ ã‚º ã‚¶ ãƒãƒˆãƒªãƒ³ã‚° ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ) is a collectible card game inspired by events in the anime of the same name.

Game-play focuses on the competitors in the Astradan empire's premier bloodsport: Armored Trooper (AT) Battling.

Be the first to exhaust your opponent's deck in an effort to destroy their AT and take your place among Uoodo's finest.

BigBep Hockey is designed to play quickly while providing accurate statistics. But most of all, the game is designed to feel like hockey and provide the gamer with an enjoyable and immersive experience.

BigBep Hockey utilizes a Fast Action Deck and a Fast Results deck to greatly enhance the speed of play. The vast majority of all results are found without consulting outside charts. Once you have learned the rules, contests in BigBep hockey fly by.

While the game plays rapidly, this isn’t a watered down hockey game, nor is it a quick-play game. This is a full-fledged simulation of hockey. In BigBep Hockey each skater is rated for the following: Shooting from various places on the ice, Power Play ability, Penalty Killing ability, Overall Offensive contribution, Overal Defensive Contribution, shots allowed, intimidation, passing, face-offs, injury frequency, times penalized, and a clutch rating. Goalies are also rated for both home and away performance. BigBep Hockey truly captures the entire game of hockey.

The board game includes complete rules, 100 die-cut, full-color Fast Action Cards, 100 die-cut, full-color Fast Result Charts, and all charts, printed in full-color, that are needed to play the game.

The first game in the Armor Grid System is Armor Grid: Mech Attack!  With an innovative game system and print and play 15mm scale Mech, Vehicle, and Infantry miniatures, this is a game of sci-fi mechanized military combat in skirmish and wargame scales.  Compete against your friends in one-on-one duels or extended military campaigns.

The board game shows a map of the eastern half of the world: Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia with part of Alaska.

The game is played by following the pattern of circles numbered 2 to 50. Circles 9,11,16,19,24,40 and 45 are red and represent rewards; circles 2,3,8,13,17,18,22,29,36,37,41,42,46 and 49 are white and represent forfeits. The rest of the circles are blue. You start at Berlin.

Published in Germany.

Flip your hoops onto dolphins to win! Be the first player to score 50 points.

An electronic base unit containing 4 colored dolphin heads is turned on and rotates around while dolphin heads bob up and down.  Each player places one of his 10 rings on his seal's tail and flips the tailback to release the ring.  Players keep flipping rings until all 10 have been used.  This constitutes a round. AT the end of a round scores are tallied : 
A ring around a large spinning dolphin of your color: 5 points
A ring around and large color spinning dolphin: 3 points
A ring around any stationary gray dolphin: 1 point

Players keep playing round until a someone reaches a total score of 50 points.

This is a football simulation performed with the cards.
It's possible to simulate any football game, a player against the other or in teams.
Players move with the launch of one or two dice on a default path, trying to end their movement on the boxes that allow him to play cards to attack.
If your opponent has cards appropriate defense, interrupts the action of attack and can leave again becoming he attacker, otherwise the first player to draw cards that will enable him to perform actions prior to center field, then in the area up to the shot.
A goal is scored when launching the special dice, you get the symbol on.
The game ends when the entire path will be traced. 
Obviously wins whoever  marked the most goals.
It is possible to conclude the match in a draw.

A Memory Matching Game with a Spin!
A new take on the classic memory game, S'Match challenges young players to find matching pairs by color, number or category. Only here, it's the S'Match Spinner that decides which way to match-and every player gets a spin! Pictures and words allow pre-readers and early readers to play together and enjoy hours of memory-building fun.

The object of the game is to place all of your pieces onto the playing surface before your opponent can place all of theirs.

Each player receives 18 pieces in their colour.  The pieces either show a 'rock', 'scissors', or 'paper' symbol.  Each turn you must play your "reserve" tile that you selected the previous turn, and then select a new tile for your reserve, anticipating your opponent's next move.  Placements rules are basically that your symbol must overpower at least one other symbol beside it (using standard rock-scissors-paper rules.)  You lose a turn if you can't place your reserve piece onto the board, and you must then choose a new reserve piece for your next turn.

From the box: "New Family Game. Official Game of Medieval Times Dinner & Tournament. The Epic Game of Tournament Competition."

From the inner box: "My noble knights, you honor me with your presence. I Don Raimundo II, Count of Perelada, welcome you to my castle for a tournament of games. Now let the tournament begin!"

From the rules: "Be the first player to obtain all four tournament Victory Cards and present them to the Count and Countess at the Victory Banquet. The four tournaments are as follows: Sword Fighting, Ring Piercing, Jousting, Javelin throwing."

User summary: The game consists of a rolled-up cloth-backed faux-leather board with all four events located around the castle along with--in each corner--the sequence of moves to participate in each event; Fate cards, Victory cards in four colors: Salmon, Blue, Yellow and Green. 4 pewter knights in each of those colors; one die and the rules.

User summary:
It is 'a tactical game that plays a Formula 1 race.
Established the grid through the roll of the dice, players take turns moving on the track, always throwing the dice.
Overtaking is allowed only in some parts of the circuit, so if we get a greater number of who goes before us but we can not overcome it, we can accumulate the points are not used to do so later (the primordial idea of KERS!).
Along the track there are also boxes of penalty that we are forced to miss turns, forced a pit stop etc....
The race includes the pit stop to change tires every 3 laps.
After the number of laps set earlier in the game (minimum 4) wins who crosses the finish line first.

From box:
An original game, exciting, full on the Italian language.
3000 questions on 13 different topics: plurals,contrarys, foreign words, literature, mistakes ....
The simple and fast strategy involves and will challenge all players with fun challenges, risks, exciting and thrilling competition.

The children use either the dice with colours or the dice with dots. Depending on the colour or number of dots that come up when the dice is thrown the children build towers and the winner is the one who stacks the bricks skilfully and produces the highest tower! Mini-Torreta will be delivered in a small cotton bag.

In this fun game for the whole family, players must help Rasmus Klump in gathering the things he'll need to bake a great pile of delicious pancakes with jam.
On their way, around the whole farm and the mill to gather the things, all the players will meet a lot of different animals, to whom they will have to speak to in "animal-language" - "Oink" for the pig, "meow" for cat, and so on.

From the back of the box:

Mixing and Matching fun for all ages.
Players roll the die and try to make as many mixed up comical characters as they can, choosing and combining card parts from different figures. The object then is to try to make complete figures by winning cards from other players. Each complete character scores one point, and the player with the most points wins!

From the Publisher's Website:

Wargaming the Wars of Napoleon Bonaparte.

Brought to you by the same team behind Beneath the Lily Banners, the book combines  the writing of Barry Hilton with the creative talents of illustrator and designer Clarence Harrison. The book is lavishly illustrated with over 200 original photographs shot especially.

150 pages of full colour with 210 photographs of some of the finest wargaming models around. The rules come with a six sided gate-fold full colour play sheet on thick gloss finish card.

The rules require no rebasing of collections. Unit basing is immaterial as long as it follows the general conventions of tabletop gaming. Republic to Empire can be used for all scales although they are primarily written for 28mm scale Divisional to Army level games.

Unit sizes can vary from 16-60 for infantry and 10 – 60 for cavalry. The game play is smooth and free flowing with minimal need to refer to the main text once concepts have been mastered. New players usually pick up the key mechanisms within three to four game turns.
 The rules contain comprehensive detail on

Scales – Creating your Army – Setting up the game – Command and Orders – Exploitation – Formations and Movement – Terrain effects – Skirmishers – Play Sequence – Artillery – Shooting – Charging – Close Combat – Resolve – Fighting in Built up Areas.

The text is laid out in a way that separates:

Background information on concepts

Core rule mechanisms

Examples of mechanisms at work

There a 10 page fully illustrated example game from the 100 Days Campaign with full detail from orbat construction to conclusion.

Special rules sections to cover adaption for the Revolutionary Wars Period and the 1812 War in North America are also included.

A two player simulation of the Finnish Civil War that cost the lives of over 37,000 Finns. The war was fought in Finland from 27 January to 15 May 1918 between the forces of the Social Democrats led by the People's Deputation of Finland, commonly called the "Reds", and the forces of the non-socialist, conservative-led Senate, commonly called the "Whites". The Reds were supported by Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, while the Whites received military assistance from Sweden and the German Empire.

The game consists of a 3D plan of a little cottage. There are two platforms on each side of the roof where Hansel climbs to throw down ginger.

Below stands Gretel who catches the pieces of ginger. There are six places where Gretel can stand on each side of the cottage and each side of the roof.

You can move Hansel and Gretel according to the throw of the dice. Hansel can move one platform up or down, and Gretel can move to an adjacent place on the ground. A third option given on the dice is for Hansel to throw down one ginger by sliding new tile from the bundle on the table.

Each platform of the roof consists of six ginger tiles. On the other side of the tile are one or three almonds, but there can also be a witch who can catch Gretel and force her to give up one ginger tile.

The game ends when there are no tiles to put on the roof. Whoever has collected the most almonds wins.

Blue Chip is played on a 8x8 square board. On each turn each player must do the next two things:

1. Pass or move one of his stones as a "runaway queen" (i.e., to the last empty cell in any direction, but not to any closer square), if and only if the stone is orthogonally adjacent to a neutral blue stone at the start of its move.

2. Pass or move a neutral blue stone as a "runaway queen", if and only if it is orthogonally adjacent to any non-neutral stone (red or white) at the start of its move. If this move leaves the stone orthogonally adjacent to a red or white stone, the same stone may move again, and so on.

GOAL - A player wins when his first row is filled with stones, including at least one of his color. If neither player's first row is filled yet neither player is able to move, the last player who moved loses.

A strategy/fantasy game played on two decks of standard poker-style playing cards, the basic idea behind The Grass of Parnassus was to create a fun strategy game which could be played on standard cards.

Each player has a city. The objective is to either build your city to a strength of 15 or to pummel your enemy's city to a strength of zero. Each player holds two "decks" of cards - a resource and action deck. Action cards may be played if the player has the corresponding resource cards to spend. Actions include strenghtening your city, hiring a champion to defend your city, deploying spies and thieves, and attacking the enemy city or champion.

Though intended for two players, up to four may play at one time by adding one deck for each additional player; this may add more dimensions to the game as alliances and cooperatives may be formed and broken.

The play is not too intense, though planning a few turns ahead is essential to success.
A somewhat Blaxploitation roll and move game (spinner) where you play "Captain Soul" a Black super hero battling the forces of evil while exploring outer space.

From rules page:

Max-It is a unique dice game played with a special set of five dice. Three regular d6s and two "function" dice, each of which has two Plus (positive) signs, two Minus (negative) signs and two Times (multiplication) signs. Game play involves rolling and re-rolling the dice, and grouping them in various combinations to produce the most desired results.

The game is divided into three rounds, each with a different objective. A round consists of three turns and a Max-It roll for each player. A Max-It roll uses only two dice, one regular and one function, and may cause a scoring upset. After three rounds, each player takes a final Max-It roll. The player with the highest total score wins.

Round 1 - Players try for high positive scores.
Round 2 - Players try for high negative scores.
Round 3 - Players try for the greatest difference between two dice rolls.

Components include 5 dice (3 regular and 2 function), dice cup, instructions and players' score pad.

Follow Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, Jr., USN (1888–1957) on his trail by air, sea and land from New Zealand to the South Pole avoiding the perils of icebergs, crevasses and blizzards along your route.

Housed in the original 2 part box with color illustration on box lid depiction Admiral Byrd and scenes from his Antarctic exploration: Game board, 4 wooden game pieces, 4 spinners mounted to wooden sticks with colored cords and wooden plugs simulating radio microphones.

Object of the game is to insert peg at bottom of microphone into die-cut holes at “New Zealand”, spin the spinner and start out for Admiral Byrd’s Little America base. As players reach their destination they announce their safe arrival using the microphone and then continue on to the South Pole. The first player to reach the South Pole by exact count wins.

A set collecting, rummy card game played in multiple hands.

Players must collect 14 different card sets or "steps", one per hand,  in a specific order, with an increasing level of difficulty.  On a players turn they must draw a card, complete a step if possible or play off cards from their hand onto their own or other players steps if they have their target step "down", and discard a card to end their turn.  If player discards a playable card, another player may call "rummy", play the card from the discard, and give the discarding player a card from their own hand.  A hand of play ends when any player discards the last card from their hand.

Players score points for cards remaining in their hands at the end of each hand of play.  After completing all 14 steps, the player with the lowest score wins.

Game includes 143 card deck (featuring unsuited number cards from 1 to 13 and "Wild Bee" wild cards), a set of four unique sliding windowed step counters that allow each player to keep track of which of the 14 steps he or she is trying to "get down" next, and a large pad of score sheets.  Cards are linen finished and seem to be of high quality.  Box top is sturdy.  Inner box, with game rules printed on bottom, is somewhat flimsy.

The name of this game translates to 'Game of Parisian Monuments'. There are 63 playing spaces which represent places of interest in Paris with additional scenes in the corners. The end of the game is marked with the Arc de Triomphe. Rules are engraved in the centre of the game board.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns, taking of counters. 
Forfeits: backward movment, lose of turns, payment of counters. 
Equipment required: teetotum and playing counters.

Published in Paris, France.

Jostle is a combinatorial game (i.e. two player, perfect info, etc.), which uses a 10x10 square grid, 16 red checkers and 16 blue checkers, as shown in the figure.  On your turn you move one of your checkers to an unoccupied, orthogonally adjacent square, subject to the following.  The value of a checker is its number of friendly orthogonal adjacencies minus its number of enemy orthogonal adjacencies.  You can only move a checker when you increase the moved checker's value.  The last player to move wins.  I.e. if you don't have a move on your turn, you lose.

Publisher Blurb:

The Saints are marching back to New Orleans with their first Super Bowl Championship!

The MONOPOLY brand proudly presents the New Orleans Saints Super Bowl XLIV Champions Collector’s Edition. Buy, sell and trade Drew Brees, Reggie Bush, Darren Sharper, Marques Colston and Robert Meachem in an effort to own the NFL’s best. Relive the road to glory from their 13-game winning streak to Garrett Hartley’s game winning overtime field goal against the Vikings.

Congratulations to all Saints fans and to the city of New Orleans on your first Super Bowl victory in franchise history!

Enemy Action is a new series of card-driven war games on pivotal military operations and campaigns in the twentieth century. Each game allows for play by two players or one player, playing either side in the conflict.

The Enemy Action series features:

        Two-player competition with low complexity and constant decision points for both sides
        Solitaire play of either side with systems governing all aspects of enemy command and tactics
        Card-driven impulse system, with multi-purpose cards played to activate formations, implement command events, or gain tactical advantages in combat
        Diceless and chartless combat system – players draw combat chits that build a narrative of each combat


John Butterfield’s unique card-driven mechanic allows players to use multiple resources in multiple ways but each decision has a consequence, many of which aren’t evident at the time. Resources include units and cards. So two different cards can be used to activate the same unit/s, but each card may have a different secondary use that could include artillery support or even activation of more units (or group of units).

The combat chit system is yet another decision-making point. Players choose and reveal a number of combat chits that varies based on a number of factors. The minimum and maximum number is dependent upon unit capabilities, terrain and support, but not combat factors (so no factor counting here). This choice can often get an attacker into trouble by going for “a chit too far”… Or it might even be a masterstroke to take that extra chit…

Enemy Action: Ardennes

The first game in the series is Ardennes. The game portrays the German offensive against the western Allies in December 1944 — the Battle of the Bulge. Each player controls the German or Allied side. When playing solo, the game system controls the other side. So Enemy Action: Ardennes is effectively three games in one box: the two-player game, solitaire playing the Allies, and solitaire playing the Germans.

Map scale on this module is 2.5 miles per hex. Hexes on the game map are oversized allowing for easy counter handling. Unit scale is regiment, brigade and division, with one to four steps per unit. Each turn represents one day of the battle, with several alternating player impulses in each day.
 Components:

        3 22″x34″ maps (1 for each solitaire game and 1 for the 2-player game – only 1 is used at a time)
        3 full sheets of counters, printed both sides
        1 deck of 110 playing cards (poker quality)
        3 rules books, (1 for each game)
        Multiple player aid cards
        1 full color 3” box and lid


Complexity: Medium
    Playing Time: 15 minutes to 6 hours for the full campaign
    Solitaire Suitability: Designed for solitaire play
    Designer: John Butterfield
    Developers: John Foley
    Artist: Tim Schleif

(from Compass Games website)


BGG wiki page with many clarifications and hints and errata:
Enemy Action: Ardennes German Solo FAQ

In each corner of the sheet is a scene for a different part of the day showing a woman engaged in a relevant pursuit such as dressing and hunting.

The game board has 63 numbered compartments, each showing the head of a lady. The rules are in the centre. This game is dedicated to the beautiful sex.

This game has 100 playing spaces. Players follow a young mouse from the time he gets up in the morning until he goes to bed at night. The French instructions are printed on the game board.

All numbers and rules are in French and the game was designed to teach the language.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns. 
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turned.

The board is laid out with a tree in each corner and a clearing in the centre. Players move along pathways that connect the different areas, and they follow printed directions, which include both forfeits and rewards. In the middle of each outer edge is a store comprising four oval spaces on which players place the food they have gathered. The playing pieces represent four woodland animals: a wood mouse, a red squirrel, a bank vole and a harvest mouse.

The game requires the players to gather winter stores for the animals and attempts to instill knowledge about the animals.

Rewards: forward movement, collect items. 
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turns and forfeit of items 
Equipment required: 4 round markers of stained wood, green with a paper label showing a woodland animal, 16 tokens, ovals of printed card - four each of acorns, beechnuts, pine cones,  hazel nuts and wooden dice.

Published in the UK.

Do you love A. A. Milne's Winnie The Pooh? OK, here is the race game! On the game board one can see some of the adventures  to be found in the books of Milne.

Published in London, UK.

From the introduction of the rules set:
"Fraser's book The Steel Bonnets gives a good history of the cattle raids back and forth across the Anglo-Scottish border during Elizabeth's reign. Having visited Hexham, capital of the Middle March last year, and toured the first purpose-built gaol in England, my interest in the Border Reivers was rekindled and I devised the following game.

"Being both a wargamer and a role player I was interested in developing a fast, easy set of rules suitable for a skirmish encounter while instilling a sense of proprietary interest on the part of the players with their figures. Too often, I find, tabletop generals are willing to sacrifice their regiments with gleeful abandon, heedless of the actual cost. Role playing games generate a notion of investment and caution, with characters developed over a series of adventures. Steel Bonnets attempts to recreate the care and concern a reiver patriarch would feel for his sons and gillies when they are on raid."

Scale: One turn equals one minute; one figure equals one man; half an inch equals one yard. 20mm or 25mm figures are recommended.

Although a miniatures game, figures have individual characteristics and skills that develop over time.

This simple system includes rules for Spotting and Victory Point, as well as everything need for combat. Includes four scenarios: The Cattle Raid, Black Mail, Government Raid, & Gaol Break.

Rules set appear in Wargames Illustrated #78 (March 1994)

The boardgame has 84 playing spaces. The main title and the individual ones are in four languages: French, German, English and Polish. The aim is to reach immortality, and the end space of the game is the Immortal Man. It shows a memorial monument with an urn on the shoulders of women who stand on a column and steps, accompanied by four figures. On the memorial tablet are the words ‘MLEOPOLD/HERvBRAUNS/GEB1752GEST85’, which refer to Leopold of Brunswick, who drowned in 1785 while attempting to save people in a flood. He would have featured here as a model of selflessness, which was considered one of the qualities needed to attain eternal life.

Rewards: receipt stakes and/or moves forward, according to the rules. 
Forfeits: payment of stakes (counters) and/or moving backwards or staying an extra turn in one spot, in accordance to the rules. 
Equipment required: teetotum, one marker per player; at least 12 counters per player.

The boardgame was designed for the German and French market and uses those two languages. The starting point is a clock face numbered 1 and entitled 'Temporellite' or 'Zeirlichkeit' and the finishing point is number 33, 'Eternity'. Some of the squares require the receiving or paying of a token and some send the player forwards or backwards. The game would be played with dice. The player going out on the number 33 will win.

The game deals with the Boer Wars, two wars fought between Britain and the two independent Boer republics, the Orange Free State and the South African Republic (Transvaal Republic).  The First Anglo-Boer War (1880–1881) and The Second War (1899-1902).

This is a strategy game in which the two players attempt to reach their goals, while halting the progress of their opponent.

Tanto Cuore: Expanding the House, both a standalone game and the first expansion for Tanto Cuore, brings a garden theme to the world of maid-collecting, with construction cards such as "Garden", "Lily Garden" and "Leaving".

This is a Japanese deck-building card game which has a mechanism similar to Dominion.

Each player plays as the Lord of a mansion and hires maids to fill out their house to become the King of Maids! The end goal is simple enough, the player who has the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins! Players acquire Victory Points by employing a variety of maids and "Love" cards that allow for different strategies. You can even employ Private Maids that stick around to use their special powers each per turn! Some give you a bonus, or affect your opponents in a negative way. But beware, your opponents can make your maids sick or give them bad habits, affecting your maids in negative ways and decreasing your Victory Points!

The game art is in the Japanese anime style and uses the theme of maids commonly seen in anime! All of the cards, dividers and manual fit into an easy to transport box so you can easily take the game with you wherever you want.

Tanto Cuore: Expanding the House includes 280 cards, with artwork from 27 artists.

This game is a straightforward race game with an unusual pattern of play with 104 squares set up and down the board around the central illustration with naval warfare, which is the finish.

Published in England.

Air Raid Precautions

The illustrations on the gameboard deal with jobs done and dangers encountered during the war years.

This game is a race game with rewards and forfeits along the 120 squares. The start is the air-raid drill and the finish is the All Clear sounding. The game was inspired by the air-raid precautions (ARP) put in place in Britain before the Second World War.

A player is unveiling the lost legends of Polish. Collect the cards and travel around the game board (map Polish). Players can exchange parts of the legends of the others. The player who accumulates the most points wins the game.

Boots on the Ground puts you in the middle of the action. Start your mission as the Team leader of an elite group of shooters. Your team consists of a Demo expert, Heavy Weapons Expert, Medic, Scout, Sniper and you -- the Leader. During your briefing you are told your objectives and known intel on the area. Move your force through the urban area facing an unknown number of insurgents coming from you at all angles. As the team leader you decide if you stay as a group or send out a specialist to eliminate the enemy with their unique skills. Play solo, or fight together with another player as Alpha and Bravo team, while the insurgents move and engage you both with equal resolve thanks to a card-automation system.  You can also race to see which team can complete the objectives first, or even play as a traditional 2-sided wargame.

The players throw the three dice at one time and everyone looks together for the tile with the same shapes as those that come up on the dice. Different versions offer variety so that even older children and adults can have a lot of fun with Shapy.

The educational matching game that helps promote visual and tactile shape recognition while boosting memory skills at the same time. Different options of play and levels of difficulty mean that Tastaro is suitable for various different age groups and accelerates the learning curve in a fun way.

Contents:
• 8 wooden shapes  
• 32 wooden cards (45 x 45 x 4 mm) 
• 3 cotton pouches
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

A race game which starts at 'Enrolment' and moves counter clockwise. Accompanying the game are test cards and badges, which determine the rewards and forfeits. The winner is the one who reaches the Silver Wolf Badge.

The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are used, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed. The game is played anticlockwise. The centre of the circuit shows a vivid, modern illustration of a motorcycle race in progress, with illustrations of cycles and people in each corner.

It`s fun to go shopping! Particularly when you`re buying colourful and healthy food! Giving children the opportunity to buy the food and pay for it themselves delevops in them an awareness of nutrition, strategic thinking and an early understanding of quantities.

The players move their figures along the board and bit by bit they buy four different items of food (apples, peppers, maize and fish). They have money tokens to use to pay for them but they must make sure to get the food at the right price. The first to pay for these four food items is the winner.

Contents:
• 1 wooden playing board (appr. 370 x 370 x 10 mm) 
• 4 playing figures 
• 16 money tokens
• 1 dice with dots  
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

This game with our "Funny Friends" is convenient for the youngest. Even two years children are able to follow easy instructions. The clear shapes and colours of the game are especially age oriented.

The animals run once on the racecourse on the playing field whereby the spinning arrow decides how far each animal may run in each go. The winner is the first animal to arrive back at his start or go beyond it.

Contents:
• 1 wooden game board (400 x 400 x 10 mm) 
• 4 playing figures
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

A card game where the cards each have a letter of the alphabet and part of an illustration. The aim is to collect all the cards for one nationality.

It must be said that this is an educational game and not a game in the Happy Family category.

Published in New York.

A card game with the players trying to collect additional cards to create sets/tricks.

“First published in around 1865, when history meant learning the kings and queens, Jaques titled the 3 different games as Hide & Seek series 1 (William I - Richard II), Hide & Seek series 2 (Henry IV - Charles I) and Hide & Seek series 3 (Charles II - Victoria in the 1st edition or Edward VII in the 2nd edition). The first editions all had small pictures of the monarchs but the second editions had larger pictures in a more modern style looking like paintings. The game is played by players asking each other for the Event cards matching the King cards, completing sets, and so on.” - description taken from the World of Playing Cards website

Teach French with cards! 210 cards with pictures and names cut in half. The top half with English name and upper half of the picture, while the French name and the lower half of the picture is on the lower half of the card.

The game could be played by one person or in the same way as dominoes.

A game with 150 cards each printed with a question about music. The answers are all contained in an accompanying booklet. There are six classes of questions concerning different aspects of written music.

Class A contains Questions on the Form of the Characters, etc 
Class B Time, Rests Clefs, etc 
Class C The Names of the Lines and Spaces 
Class D Sharps, Flats, Accents, etc

Each card is printed with a title and illustration of a character, and a rhyming couplet. Each verse gives a moral lesson and a reward or forfeit.

Shuffle the cards and deal them out face downwards. The dealer commences by turning up a card and paying or receiving as directed on their card. The card with Mother Goose winning the pool and repeating the following words on turning up the card and making every player turn up whatever cards they have left:

Mother Goose by starlight flies 
On the air with golden prize, 
Her share will be the total hoard, 
When all are served she clears the board. 
The game all o'er her task is done, 
Her only aim to cause some fun. 
So now good night my children gay, 
For Goosey bids me haste away.

The game board depicts a colorful spiral. Each of the six colors has six base fields from which a spiral "arm" leads to the center of the board. The colors don't "belong" to any player. Instead, any player can use playing pieces in any color.

There are two rule sets included: 
In the "dice game", players take turns rolling four dice. With the results, they can put playing pieces on free spaces in the spiral. One die can be used to jump over another piece which is then returned to its base. When a player has occupied certain positions, he/she is awarded a number of scoring chips. The player with most chips at the end of the game is the winner.
The "board game" is a push your luck game. The pieces, which contain numbers from 1-6, are placed on their bases, face down. One piece of each color is flipped over and put on the corresponding position in that color's spiral. 
A player can now flip over pieces and move them into their position until he/she flips over a piece that is larger than a previously played piece in the same color. In that case, all pieces that were jumped over are moved back to their bases (behind the un-flipped pieces, in numerical order) and it's the next player's turn. The same scoring applies as in the dice game.

(User summary by HilkMAN - corrections welcome. The rules aren't easy to understand)
